												You may think this game is good at first. You may think that me having clocked in over 200 hours means it must be good. But really, this game is like cocaine. You'll use it once, think it's interesting, then keep going. Soon you'll know it's bad, and that it's just constantly killing you, but you'll keep going, hoping it'll go back to the good it once seemed to be. If you're lucky like me, you'll escape and never play this again.Let me explain my opinion a little more. This game is essentially an RTS with guns, tanks and artillery. That's fun and fine in itself, at least on paper, but it necessitates a few things. For example, if you have troops with guns, you expect that they'll be able to shoot enemies, and generally get things done without your constant aid. Not in Men of War. Your troops will frequently throw grenades into their own squads, waste ammo shooting at nothing (yeah, you have to keep track of every troop's ammo), miss enemies at point blank range, stare at the last sighted enemy even if they're miles out of range, stop running in favor of standing in a field trying to shoot an invisible sniper, or just flat out do something that makes no sense. This is only the beginning.Your tanks fare even worse. There is literally no way to use them apart from taking direct control of the tank, the AI for it is that useless. This limits you to having pretty much one tank on the battlefield at a time. This would be reasonable, except that the game's terribly designed engine starts to really kick in now. Even while you desperately try to aim at an enemy vehicle, your shots will typically bounce off, or just flatout prove useless, while later, while not even trying, a .50 cal will destroy the same tank with ease. The game is just littered with inconsistencies, all the while trying desperately to cling to realism. And once again, this is just the beginning.In trying to move away, so as to hopefully avoid some shots, you'll find that the terrain is just as poorly built. Tanks will simply stop at steep inclines, and will actually become a physics object upon colliding with a rock, juttering out of control for a crucial second or two, regardless of how hard your brushed against it, while it will have no problem pummelling through a block of buildings. Speaking of buildings, some, and it seems more or less entirely random, will never be properly broken and will stay standing even after you've barraged the area with artillery, while some will crumble after a few grenades come near it.There's also a huge issue with balance, with the Soviets (possibly in accordance with reality) getting not only the best tanks, but also getting them the cheapest. Forget what you've heard about American tanks being cheap, they are the most expensive to field. Germany is the only nation that can compete; Japan and Britain might as well not be playable. In theory, the American infantry is better than the Soviet, but in practice this is only true for basic infantry. Elite infantry finds home with the Soviets again, who pretty much decimate all other units, until you bring in tanks, where once again, the Soviets take the cake. You'd think maybe some artillery would take out them out, but it proves rather fruitless, because they also get very good light vehicles, which will take out whatever artillery you have.This is all without even getting into the abomination that is the single player mode. The voice acting is cringeworthy; nearly on par with Zelda CDI. The difficulty curves make no sense, ranging from Niagra Falls drops, to brick wall inclines, and there's an extremely shallow learning curve, with the tutorial teaching you only a quarter of what you actually need to know to play effectively. On top of that, the singleplayer AI is completely insane, relying more on fielding impossibly large amounts of units than actually being able to control any.But I could go on forever. I'm going to cut my time spent with this game short and now try my best never to think of it again. Do yourself a favour and don't ever touch this game.

Men of War Review - Rating: 8.3/10General ImpressionMen of War is a pretty nice strategy game. The graphics look pretty old, the textures are not great either, but they suit Men of War, because it is the first Men of War ever created. The old looking of the graphics really make this game look like the first one ever off a sequel, so I personally don’t see it as a negative point. Plus that strategy games weren’t looking great back then either. The atmosphere mostly happens in open fields, villages, cities, forests, and even other environments. The audio is pretty nice. I like the sound of the guns, tanks, etc. The music is very nice, it will always keep you with the wish to kill your enemy. The voice acting is very good as well. The gameplay is complex, in each mission you have to accomplish some tasks, alike killing certain enemies, cleaning fields off enemies, destroying some units, reaching a point, capturing a point, holding off certain positions, etc. The story focuses on the Soviet, Allied or German forces. They will have many battles in the 19 missions available, some of them being the Bonus ones, in the 4th and last campaign. The cut scenes of the missions are also pretty nice. The user interface is well-optimized, with no bugs and well-synthetized information. I also like the overall design of it. The controls are pretty good, except with 1 thing: the rotations’ controls of the cameras. I highly recommend you to reset them with the arrow buttons. The engines, just like in every Men of War game, are not perfect. The game has rarely crashes, and when it crashes, you obviously lose the progress of your mission. Try and save the game as often as you can, in order to avoid too much progress lose. You don't want to waste your time by restarting the mission from zero, right? The mechanics are sophisticated, being pretty nice and everything moves well-optimized. Now, I’m going to talk a little about the G.E.M. editor. Just like in every Men of War game, you have a G.E.M. editor. You can create your own battles in it. It is complex and with a various number of functions. What I don’t like in this particular G.E.M. editor: the amount of content. Compared to Men of War: Assault Squad 1 and 2, this game has less content, especially in the G.E.M. editor. But overall, the G.EM. editor is pretty nice, still. Overall this game is a pretty nice simulations of the battles of the Soviet, Allied and German forces during World War 2.Positive PointsPretty nice and well-designed graphics and texturesPretty nice audio and nice musicFun and challenging gameplayMany missions throughout the 4 campaigns availableInfantry, heavy guns, batteries, cannons, vehicles, tanks, airplanes, and many other units available 3 difficulties availableA pretty nice designed user interface, and some well-deisgned cutscenesSome pretty stable enginesSome pretty nice mechanicsNeutral PointsTrading cards would be a nice featureMore units would be awesomeThe editor should have more content, including being able to drive airplanesNegative PointsThe multiplayer is not alive anymoreThere are some rare crashes, like in all the Men of War games

												This game is brilliant.I know that's not a proper review so let's go into more detail: this game is really ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant.Okay seriously now...I have just spent 27 hours completing the first campaign with the Soviets, on normal. Yes that is my entire playtime. No I do not suck at wargames. This game is hard, and not always for the right reasons. Aside from the fact that I traditionally play as a virtual Montgomery (yes, the WWII Field Marshal known for his caution and methodical attacking strategy), Men of War throws things at you that I guarantee you you've never seen in any other WWII RTS. Let's get the bad out of the way first, so we can gorge on the good for dessert.If you don't like micro-management of units in an RTS, steer clear of this game. I personally consider this a good aspect of the game, but because it's on such an intense and vast scale, it can be...overwhelming. You may be in command of many dozens of men at any one time and because each and every individual gets their own inventory (more on that later), that's dozens of people whose weapons and ammo loadouts you generally need to keep an eye on.What really gets on my nerves, and will get on yours, are the small terrain bugs. This is a problem that applies mainly to vehicles and large equipment like anti-tank guns. This may be a tech constraint more than anything else but it seems where they've tried to map out terrain accurately, they've ended up not quite getting it right, so your vehicles/equipment sometimes end up going very, very slowly over pieces of terrain that are not completely smooth. The whole issue is a minor thorn in your leg but it's still bothersome.Finally, the game is often difficult because you are given barebones assistance in terms of objectives. To be clear, yes you are given objectives and yes there's a red arrow that points to objectives during missions. But it's a thick red ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that really only points to the general region of your objective rather than the specific item or area, and your objectives are not always explained clearly enough. What I mean by that is, the game tells you what to do but it doesn't do it specifically enough. Minor spoiler ahead if you want more of an explanation on that: Take the final mission of the Soviet campaign for instance. There's a point in it where you have to release a submarine from a small pen and the game instructs you to do this, but not how to do it. I spent ten to fifteen minutes trying to figure it out, launching Panzerfausts at the dock power station, thinking blowing it up would achieve my aim (and because it usually does in many WWII RTS games- silly me). It doesn't, and I'm left puzzled as to what I need to do. Turns out there's a small console on one of the power pylons which will open the gate to the pen. GO FIGURE.Now, if you can at least tolerate all that then please, please, stay for the brilliance.Anyone who is familiar with games like Company of Heroes will feel right at home with this game. Only you're not at home because THIS. IS. MEN OF WAR. First thing you might notice is how there's no base. Instead you're given a complement of troops each mission. Every single soldier you can click on has their own inventory box. Literally every single one. They can pick up [and use] most anything and everything you can find on the battlefield, ranging from helmets and grenades to ammunition boxes and rocket launchers. You could probably play this game as some kind of Inventory Collection Simulator 2009. Now, the best thing about this is essentially unit customization.You cannot customize the looks of your men but by ♥♥♥♥ you can customize damn near everything else. Want to go into battle with a squad of bazooka-armed Nazi officers? Done. Want to strip your men to the bare bones and send them into battle as nothing but trained martial artists? You're covered there. Just want to craft a well-armed, well-rounded squad with rifles and a couple of light machine guns? Go for it! The game practically begs you to do this and the system is self-perpetuating because EVERY SINGLE soldier on the battlefield has their own inventory, even your opponents. On a special forces mission and in need of some heavier weapons? Tough luck. Oh wait, I can hear the deep growl of a truck coming this way, get ready lads...Another highly celebrated feature of this game is the Direct Control system. Using this you can essentially play through entire missions as one soldier or one vehicle. The system does precisely what it claims to do and gives you control over a single entity in the game, thereafter moving it around with the arrow keys and aiming/shooting with the mouse. This is not only massive bucketfuls of fun but it's paticularly useful if you want to accomplish specific tasks or turn the tide in a small tactical skirmish. I can't explain in words how satisfying it is to have one of your squads in trouble, losing men fast, only for their prayers to be answered as YOU turn the corner in a T-34, traverse the turret in the direction of your enemy and BOOM, ♥♥♥♥ YOU. Yes, the game has those moments, providing you want to make them. You can of course play this game completely as a traditional RTS and it's likely you'll spend more time directing squads and tanks at the strategic level than "on the ground". But it's those "on the ground" moments that really drive home the fun- ahem I mean, brutality of war. Graphics-wise the game is nothing particularly special. It was released in 2009 but it uses a slighly older engine so don't expect too much polish. You can still observe troops getting pulverized into a fine mist by 20mm FlaK fire, let's put it that way. Another great feature, though more minor in comparison to the others, is the way the game crafts what I like to think of as a "persistent battlefield". In most missions you will be accompanied by AI-controlled friendly troops. These guys all have their own programs and will get on with hurting the enemy wherever they can. They will even accomplish main game objectives for you in some instances. One mission I had, focused on the titanic struggle for the Seelowe Heights (anyone who knows their history will know this is a particularly bloody episode in the book of WWII) in 1945, ended up with me relying on my AI friends to clear out the enemy towards the end of the mission, as every assault I made had been pummeled into near nothingness and I ended up having no reserves left to commit. Instead, all I had left was one squad of tank crewmen.Now, if there's one thing this game teaches you like nothing else ever will, it's that failure is not the end. Only the beginning. This is where anecdotal value really comes into its own...You know what I did with that tank squad? Yeah that's right. Instead of giving up I searched the battlefield and, lo and behold, found myself a Mark IV Panzer that still had all its parts on the same vehicle (as opposed for instance to the turret being found hundreds of metres away having been blown clean off). With a heart full of vengeance, I commanded my squad to retrieve a repair kit from the inventory of an earlier destroyed T-34 and set about repairing the Panzer. My crewmen and I looked in disgust at the white cross. "We'll drape a red flag over that cross soon enough brothers", thought I. In minutes, to my deep satisfaction, my crewmen had a fully functioning Panzer, armed with a 75mm main gun on the turret and the deadly MG-34 in the hull and coax positions.I would love to finish that story (the bulk of it is we unleashed that vengeance) but Steam only lets me type so many letters. Anyway, the point is, if you hadn't already got it, this game is a main course of amazing with a starter of hard and a side order of occasionally frustrating. Do yourself a favour and buy it.

												This is still the best Men of War game made. The graphics may not be the best, and the voice acting is♥♥♥♥♥♥(hilariously), but this still trumps the other games by far. The only other game that is comparable is Faces of War, which was the game that came before MoW. MoW: Red Tide at least tried to stay close to it's roots, but suffered massively from the huge difficulty spike (compared to the original MoW) and the lack of any sort of Multiplayer (I mainly play single player games, but MoW was my exception). MoW: AS and MoW: AS2 completely changed the way the games were played previously. Changing it to more of a 'capture the flag' type game mode. Gone were the interesting characters, story, and missions. Instead you just get to play a bunch of scenario type maps that continually open up as you capture more 'flags'. That is not the MoW I enjoyed. Lastly, 1C decided to milk the series with a bunch of terrible spin-offs that I hope no one ever has to experience. The two most prominent ones being MoW: Vietnam (♥♥♥♥ing terrible game), and MoW: Condemned Heroes (which I never played, but have seen playthroughs of...it is terrible as well). They have also started to use the engine to allow a bunch of indie/small developers to make some MoW-lite games based in other periods (such as WW1, Civil War, and Modern times). None of these, however, have been able to stack up to the original Men of War. I don't understand why 1C decided to waste the success of Men of War on all these stupid spin-offs. They could have made a Men of War 2, just using the Modern engine, and with the same kind of experience MoW 1 had. But no, they'll just keep wasting the potential that Men of War had on these stupid games that are completely different from what Men of War originally was.Overall, I'd give this game a solid 8.5/10. It isn't perfect, and has many issues, but it is still the best game that the 'series' has come up with. It's just a shame that this will never see a proper sequel that will live up to it's name-sake.

												Men of War is one of the gaming industry's biggest accomplishments, settling once of for all the debate of whether games can be considered to be art. Men of War is one of gaming's first autobiographical games which follows the heavy metal band Manowar from their inception during the 1980s. The game has a beautiful opening scene wherein the player controls bassist Joey DeMaio while he snorts the biggest line of cocaine in his life while backstage at a Black Sabbath concert, and neglects to fulfill his duties as a sober fireworks manager. In this sequence the player must complete a series of quick-time-events in order to guide a stumbling Demaio into correctly setting off the fireworks in order to not burn the stage down. During this sequence the quick-time-events get harder to the point where the player cannot complete them, which reveals that Ross the Boss is right beside you and like a true bro, covers over for DeMaio and succeeds in not causing the death of Ronnie James Dio. DeMaio and Ross the Boss become best bros at that moment and start legendary metal band Manowar.The rest of the game is a re-tooled version of Activision's Guitar Hero, but all of the songs are from Manowar.

												One of the best, if not the best, WW2 tactical RTS. There is no base nor are there any resources to harvest/gather. All you have is specialized Infantry and the armoured vehicles to blow the whole map up, literally. Every single unit in the game has its own inventory space, so when you run out of ammo you better go loot it from the corpses and destroyed tanks. A combination of Commandos:Behind Enemy Lines and Sudden Strike, it delivers a refreshing perspective on RTS games. No single battle unfolds the same way twice, since the game engine and mechanics allow for a myriad of different approaches to completing your objectives.Highly recommended for experienced RTS players and WW2 battle enthusiasts

												Men of War doesn't give much in terms of a "quality" story through cutscenes, but what it does give is a quality story through gameplay.  The in-depth mechanics and ability to direct-control a unit provide you with a deep personal connection to the soldiers on the battlefield.  The missions themselves are arduous; one false move can abruptly end things, but thankfully autosave is fairly merciful.  These high-stakes only reinforce the earlier point about a personal connection to units, you feel pride when your men of war overcome impossble odds through cunning planning and strategic use of grenades.Overall, it's very hard to get into due to some very tough early missions and a very confusing interface, but once you remove all expectations brought on by previous RTS games, you'll find something that's pure brilliance.

												Men of War is the almost-classic installment in the Men of War series, Faces of War being the second and Soldiers: Heroes of World War 2 being the first. This is the first title with "Men of War". It has more modern graphics than its predecessors and has quite the long amount of missions. It also has bonus missions.Pros:- Realistic warfare simulator. Strategy matters and every little detail counts.- Has a long campaign with bonus missions.- Has nice graphics for its time.- Only game that has this level of creativity, detail, difficulty, realism and fun in a RTS.- Has an editor so you can make your own battles and mess around.- Lists of other cool things!Cons:- The micromanagement can get a little annoying.- The HUD is a mess.- Small AI bugs or random things(which are usually funny).- Well... thats about it.I have to recommend this game. If you have the money, consider the other story titles(Condemned Heroes, Red Tide, Vietnam) or the multiplayer based with SP skirmish missions titles Assualt Squad and Assualt Squad 2. That said, its worth trying out the earlier titles. There is mods that bring the Faces of War campaign and the Red Tide campaign to MOW AS2.

Men of War requires a lot of patience and good friends to enjoy it. I recommend it because of its depth. The depth is also its greatest flaw.Both the campaign and multiplayer suffer from incompetent AI but the value in each unit assuages this. If you're dealing with a whole platoon things get messy. The biggest problem is that each unit has their own inventory, including ammo, helmets, hats, weapons, tools, and chickens.Yes, chickens.This feature causes a lot of frustration. The player must resupply and check up on each soldier and vehicle for them to continue fighting or else incompetence ensues. This micromanagement is the biggest flaw of Men of War and is one that's hard to get over. Leave units unattended, and they lose all of their organization. The units need the player to survive.Men of War's strength comes from Direct Control. Direct Control allows the player to use the mouse and kewyboard to move or shoot any of their tanks, troops, turrets, etc. Direct Control can make the difference in any battle because it lets creative combat take place. A well placed grenade thrown by a submachinegunner hidden in the rubble destroys a heavy tank's engine. An armoured car weaves through tight alleys and flanks a set of anti-tank guns. A machinegun set up at the right angle annihilates an entire squad.If you want a realistic RTS game that rewards creativity, buy Men of War. If you want a simple game, avoid it.

 Originally posted on March 28, 2011 --- UPDATED REVIEW 10/26/2016 (see below) Men of War is certainly unique. In no other true RTS have I been able to (and indeed required to) manage the inventory of individual soldiers. Each soldier must carry a specific weapon which they may or may not be proficient at using, ammo, a helmet, bandages, and even knives or entrenchment tools. Each vehicle has fuel and ammo which can be replenished, and each seat must be manned by an individual soldier. Combine this with a fairly realistic ballistics and penetration model (infantry are REALLY vulnerable, and certain tanks simply cannot be penetrated by small rounds) and you have some very micro-heavy gameplay with a good degree of realism. The problem is that the AI is absolutely terrible in single player, and the game pits you against laughably sized hordes of them to compensate for it. While as a history nut I loved the amount of detail and flavor in the vehicles and weapons that were available, the AI and level design undoes almost all of this. The result is a massive amount of save whoring and gamey behavior to exploit the AI. In multiplayer, the variety of units and weaponry is much appreciated, but the gameplay itself is directionless. You can capture points, but nothing you do in game can change the steady stream of points you receive which allow you to unlock more units. The variety of units and size of maps means that there is a hugely wasted opportunity here, because as long as you have the points, you can buy the most advanced tank or infantry unit from the start. There's no hierarchy or sense of progression, and points are seemingly randomly scattered throughout the maps.Ultimately, Men of War has an appealing level of micro, but fails in terms of direction.UPDATED REVIEW 10/26/2016:After more than five years, I ended up playing Soldiers: Heroes of World War II, and replaying Men of War pretty extensively. Below are my thoughts.Pro:- While pretty much all of what I said regarding Men of War's excessive micromanagement is still true, I've come to see the insane level of detail as more of a positive. Especially after playing Soldiers first, I've come to appreciate the potential for creating your own narrative within Men of War's detailed sandboxes. I think you have to be the right kind of crazy to like this kind of thing, but once you do, its very addictive.- Sandbox gameplay increases replay value and encourages creativity.- Environmental destruction is impressive. I'd say it's actually more detail than Company of Heroes' system, even if it looks less cinematic at times. For example, walls can be destroyed in smaller chunks, and when buildings collapse they remain a part of the environment, providing cover instead of just becoming a giant obstacle.- The variety of historical vehicles is insane. As a history nerd, this pleases me enormously.- Campaigns are focused on lesser-known battles in WWII.Con:- Using Direct Control is still a requirement to beat most single player missions, when it should be just a neat feature. This is because of the incompetence of the AI - you simply can't leave your units unattended for very long, or expect them to make that crucial shot. You have to do it yourself.- The micro intensive nature of the game means that its easy to feel overwhelmed by the larger defense missions. This series feels most in touch with its roots when you are in control of just a squad or two.- Extensive save-whoring is still required to beat most missions.- The voice acting is horrible, and other RTS titles (Company of Heroes, Starcraft 2) are much better at using voice acting and cinematics to further the narrative.- Multiplayer modes pale in comparison to contemporaries such as Company of Heroes.Overall, I'd say the Men of War series is unlike any RTS I've played, and as I said, you have to be a certain kind of crazy to enjoy it. But it can be a lot of fun.

Posted: October 25, 2014
												A superb tactical inventory management simulator. Men of War is at its best when it is exploring the intricacies of men carrying things.  Gripping shuffling-crap-back-and-forth action is, however, occasionally interrupted by other soldiers with different uniforms who show up at random and shoot at your own troops.  The only function of this feature, as far as I can tell, is to deplete your own ammunition; if one of your units dies it's either entirely shruggable or a nigh-mission-failure anyway, so it doesn't matter much.And ammunition micromanagement is what Men of War excels at.  It's enthralling to send a truck scurrying around the map to scrape up spare machine gun ammunition for your tank which is locked in combat with a large number of enemy soldiers who are unreasonably insistent upon its demise.  There is also tons of pixelhunting fun to be had trying to click on the thing you want to click on, with tension provided by the ever-present possibility of accidentally telling a soldier to take cover on the wrong side of a wall or do something similarly bat-guano stupid.  (I'm not sure why Steam says I don't recommend this game; honestly, it's the best man-to-man cartridge-counting game around.)

												Just shooting enemies is the Missionary Position of Men of War. It gets the job done and its fun but there are about a hundred different ways to go at it.For example... How to kill a guard on a smoke break - Run him over in a vehicleStabDisarm enemy AP mine, rearm and place it then lure he and his squad over itCrush with environmental debris from explosions or with the burnt out husk of a destroyed enemy vehicle that you push like a bulldozer over him.Guns & GrenadesBare handedThrowing knife while hidden prone in tall grassAir Support & Artillary of several different varieties if availableAnd you may be thinking... ok yeah so what?. Well, the point is that this game offers all of that OR you can zoom out until infantry are the size of ants and control a column of tanks and armored vehicles in real time... then slow down time and zoom in to the drivers seat of one of your jeeps and make the driver get out and man a machine gun nest whose previous occupant was killed AND if you really think it through you can make that driver pull his jeep up to provide soft cover from one side to protect him from being flanked. Once defending against a wave of german armor I barely survived until reinforcements came, when they did I was allowed to call in heavy tanks and I did... when I took them to chase the germans accross a frozen river one of my largest tanks cracked the ice and fell in - then I realized I could break the ice to prevent their lighter armor from crossing.I was instructed to take a fortified position with a wave of infantry.I broke from the main group to comandeer a truck so I could hopefully pick up enough speed to make it over the trenches and then ram into the machine gunners sandbags with hopefully enough force to dislodge or kill him (this in itself says a lot as this isn't a canned animation or a suggested tactic, or a button - it's just something you figure out because the game apparently has a fairly robust implementation of object physics; destroyed vehicles sometimes explode and sometimes dont depending on what happened to them but if they do explode the pieces land wherever the force of the explosion takes them and then can be used as cover).

												A neat little game made for folks who enjoy micromanagement, and like bit more realistic stuffs. You can group your soldiers into groups, but can direct them independently of course. Ah, and all of them have their own inventories with ammo, weapons, grenades, and so forth. So, your average Joe can hold an SMG, an LMG, a rifle, and buttloads of grenades. Okay, it might not be entirely historically accurate, but gives the game some enjoyable moments as you can pick soldiers that will be assigned to special tasks as you take direct control of them - yep, this game has direct control. Press End, and your dreams can come true. It doesn't really work when you have multiple platoons to take care of, but on missions where you have just a small group of soldiers at your disposal, it's awesome. Also, direct controlled tanks are awesome - take aim, and disable enemy tanks' turrets. Enemy soldiers will leave the vehicle, and your MGs can easily take care of them. And then...Grand Theft Wehrmacht happens. Hop in with a single soldier, drive the tank back behind your lines, repair it, put some additional bods into it, and bam, you have a fully functional tank to crush your enemies and see them driven before you. Also, it saves reinforcements - if you are lucky and have some skills, you can finish maps without losing your own tanks and using only looted enemy vehicles. And, it's challenging. Even on Normal you'll have some hard times, if you are not too much into micromanagement, and you aren't a really freakin hardcore strategist. But if you learn the basics, you'll have really good times with this game, and feel growing desire to get each and every one of them. Sadly it lacks proper skirmish where you get a map and battle the AI, but there are enough missions to counter this. Sadly this game was supported by GameSpy, and I'm not sure if you can get it working with Hamachi, but it's worth a try if you and your friends are looking for some WW2 carnage. Especially recommended for wargamers.

												Unforgiving World War II Real-time strategy game. What could be better! The genius of the game is it's frangible/breakable environments and the ability to strategically attack a situation in a variety of ways. Are you gonna take out that entrenched 88 with an infantry attack? Attack it head-to-head with a tank? Try to flank it with multiple tanks? Try an air strike? Drop behind it with a paratrooper? Or just run it over with a lightning tank manuever? Time can be slowed down, paused or sped up. Single-player campaigns are historic and fun. Keep in mind that the game is difficult and frustrating at the best of times - but each play-through creates all kinds of random options. Animations, sounds and explosions are top-notch. Micro-management is highly detailed. My favorite modern RTS!

												A neat little game made for folks who enjoy micromanagement, and like bit more realistic stuffs. You can group your soldiers into groups, but can direct them independently of course. Ah, and all of them have their own inventories with ammo, weapons, grenades, and so forth. So, your average Joe can hold an SMG, an LMG, a rifle, and buttloads of grenades. Okay, it might not be entirely historically accurate, but gives the game some enjoyable moments as you can pick soldiers that will be assigned to special tasks as you take direct control of them - yep, this game has direct control. Press End, and your dreams can come true. It doesn't really work when you have multiple platoons to take care of, but on missions where you have just a small group of soldiers at your disposal, it's awesome. Also, direct controlled tanks are awesome - take aim, and disable enemy tanks' turrets. Enemy soldiers will leave the vehicle, and your MGs can easily take care of them. And then...Grand Theft Wehrmacht happens. Hop in with a single soldier, drive the tank back behind your lines, repair it, put some additional bods into it, and bam, you have a fully functional tank to crush your enemies and see them driven before you. Also, it saves reinforcements - if you are lucky and have some skills, you can finish maps without losing your own tanks and using only looted enemy vehicles. And, it's challenging. Even on Normal you'll have some hard times, if you are not too much into micromanagement, and you aren't a really freakin hardcore strategist. But if you learn the basics, you'll have really good times with this game, and feel growing desire to get each and every one of them. Sadly it lacks proper skirmish where you get a map and battle the AI, but there are enough missions to counter this. Sadly this game was supported by GameSpy, and I'm not sure if you can get it working with Hamachi, but it's worth a try if you and your friends are looking for some WW2 carnage. Especially recommended for wargamers.
